block.p: The president of Estonia said that President Mikhail S. Gorbachev personally warned him against the Soviet republic's following Lithuania in declaring independence.
The president of Estonia said that President Mikhail S. Gorbachev personally warned him against the Soviet republic's following Lithuania in declaring independence.
The president of Estonia said that President Mikhail S. Gorbachev personally warned him against the Soviet republic's following Lithuania in declaring independence.
Youths in Estonia are defying the Soviet military
A Soviet crackdown in Lithuania could wipe out much of the progress that has been made in Soviet-American relations in the last year, Secretary of State Baker told Foreign Minister Shevardnadze.

News analysis: As Nelson Mandela prepares to meet with President F. W. de Klerk, doubts persist about the readiness of the A.N.C. to undertake serious negotiations with the government in South Africa.

King Baudouin I of Belgium was temporarily suspended from power by the civilian Government after he declared that he could not in good conscience as a Roman Catholic sign a new law permitting abortion.
To ease harsh drought, Greeks try prayer
U.S. panel is told of Pan Am security flaws
The top economic policy makers from the U.S. and its six main industrial allies will discuss the momentous political and economic changes that have swept the world when they meet in Paris Saturday.
The Israeli Labor Party said it had acquired sufficient commitments to command a majority in Parliament and form a new Government.
Bonn to investigate two concerns over Libyan deal

A new Constitution for Hong Kong was approved by China, giving the territory some autonomy after it returns to Chinese control in 1997. The Chinese legislature also approved a new law on joint ventures.
Talks to end El Salvador's civil war will begin in May under an agreement signed by representatives of the U.S.-backed Government and the rebel movement opposing it.
Castro is unbending on Cuba's future

T. Timothy Ryan Jr. was confirmed by the Senate as the nation's top regulator of the savings and loan industry, enabling the Government to resume seizing insolvent institutions and continue the giant bailout.
Industry is wary on Senate's clean-air measure

The war on drugs in Washington has failed, Bush Administration officials have concluded. The fingerpointing has begun, with Federal and city officials blaming each other for the drug crisis in the nation's capital.
Washington at Work: Tower replays loss of coveted job
Crimes motivated by prejudice would be recorded by the Federal Government for the first time under legislation approved by the House and sent to President Bush.
Substitutes for chlorofluorocarbons, widely used substances that are destroying the Earth's protective ozone layer, could contribute significantly to long-term global warming, scientists say.

Some of Kansas City's black students can transfer to predominantly white suburban schools at the state's expense, a Federal court ruled. The decision is stirring partisans in the city's long-running legal battle.
What can go wrong in census? 2.3 million undelivered packets
The Charles Stuart murder case is still being investigated. In a bitterly contested move, prosecutors are trying to force Mr. Stuart's lawyer to testify before a grand jury.
The risk of heart attack was substantially cut when middle-aged men were given help to stop smoking, lower their blood pressure, lose weight and go on cholesterol-lowering diets, a study found.
Minnesota moves to curb cigarette machines
Gene that causes spinal disease is isolated
Bush favors bill on AIDS immigrants
Two researchers spell ''I.B.M.,'' atom by atom

Tardiness has its rewards at P.S. 94. It means the opportunity to be taken in hand by Barbara Williams, the security guard - and matriarch - of the overcrowded, understaffed school in the northern Bronx.
The president of Baruch College, which operates the nation's largest business school, announced his retirement amid uncertainty over the school's accreditation.
Donald J. Trump's Taj Mahal casino had an auspicious opening. But it came amid concern over the future of Atlantic City's $3-billion-a-year casino industry and the viability of the city.
Mr. Trump bought the lease of Bonwit Teller's flagship store in Trump Tower. Most of the retail chain will go out of business, including the main store in Manhattan.

Representative Bruce A. Morrison has changed from an underdog to the generally acknowledged front-runner among Democrats in the Connecticut gubernatorial race now that Gov. William A. O'Neill has withdrawn.
State Republicans' message that they are battling for lower taxes against a big spending Governor is finding resonance in communities like Camillus, N.Y., a suburb of Syracuse.

Board of Education officials have been asked by the hard-pressed New York City government to prepare cuts of $190 million in their budget, an amount the officials say could mean teacher layoffs and more crowded classrooms.
Rikers Island worker is shot to death during robbery
Witness says Marcos strived to hide co-op deal
Prosecution rests in slaying of New Jersey family
Playland was run as a political club, jury says
Word and Image: ''The Outsiders'' on television
Hockey: Rival coaches with similar styles

Sarah Vaughan died of lung cancer at her home in the Los Angeles suburb of Hidden Hills. A singer who brought an operatic splendor to her performances of popular standards and jazz, Miss Vaughan was 66 years old.
C. R. Smith, pioneer of aviation as head of American
Edward Oelsner, ex-president of steamship line representative
A. M. Rosenthal: We are warned
Roman Szporluk: Gorbachev's need - a diminished Russia
Walter F. Wouk: Hidden crisis in Social Security
